"The main reason the Euro exists is because Europe was, and is, afraid of going to war with itself again."

This statement is astonishing for its monumental wrongness. European banks pushed for the euro because it meant the costs of inter-euro banking would shrink spectacularly and because Europe, theoretically and incidentally, could form a trading block to compete with the US, China, and Japan. Many other potential advantages were suggested and some were actually realized. But "the main reason" the euro exists is because European banks wanted to magically and painlessly multiply their profits. That it hasn't worked that way, it can be argued, is that they too closely followed American banking practices.
Aren't you confusing the euro with the EU?

To bookmanjb -- Joe Schmoe is perfectly right. The European Economic Union, or EEU, was founded in the early '50s as a direct attempt to prevent future wars. Churchill and others had hoped for a political and a defense union as well, but these were defeated in the '50s as too invasive. Probably the economic benefits sweetened the deal for the EEU union, and made it more possible, but economic benefits were not the primary aim. The EEU is the direct antecedent of the EU.

History is your friend.

The main reason the Euro exists is because Europe was, and is, afraid of going to war with itself again.  It would be to Europe's benefit to dump the Euro, act like adults, and avoid a "civil war" without the bond of a common currency.  C'mon Europe, you're supposed to be intellectually superior to the USA aren't you?

Uh... wrong about East Asians and soybean products. It is eaten as a STAPLE food. Only until recently has meat been anything more than a condiment.

East Asians -- Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese, and Japanese -- have drunk soy milk for Thousands Of Years as a staple (East Asians don't drink milk or eat much meat, especially beef.) I remember my father telling me that he didn't remember ever seeing beef (cow meat) because it's very existence meant that some poor farmer's water buffalo (which he used for plowing and other farm labor) was dead. And everyone was lactose intolerant.

The fact is East Asians have been eating soy products for thousands of years. Hey, maybe that's why we're shorter, are less violent (check out and compare the Violent Crime rate in East Asia), are more "yellow", and do math better...

BarbPolan - I think your story is very inspirational, and I admire your sunny disposition. I am sorry that some in society do not see it that way. I certainly do, and I imagine there are many others, too. I understand and respect your comment.

BarbPolan - Thank you. You are right that more people need to know about AF. I found out about it only because a doctor discovered it during a routine physical; then I did not address the issue aggressively enough as I was changing jobs and moving from Italy to Japan. Looking back, I realize I should have had regular physicals and heeded the doctors' advice. That's a main message to all.

Jim - You are right. I am one of the lucky few. It would be good if more people understood how common strokes are, how devastating the consequences can be, how important it is to get physicals and to pay attention to what the doctor says. For the lucky, there can be a chance to recover, but I realize that is not always the case. I also realize that insurance coverage varies greatly. Thank you for your comment, and I wish you all the best and hope you derive enjoyment out of walking.

LindaP - Thank you for your note. I will read those links with interest. I don't know if exercise increased the risk of my having AF. In fact, I plan to keep my running to a moderate level and won't be looking to do many 1/2 marathons again. Just to get out there makes me feel better, and it's good to meet others, too.
Julia - You are, of course, right. I am among the very lucky few. I hope your note helps correct the public misconception.

Amy - Like Julia, you are right. I was unable to capture your experience because it was not mine. I hope I have not contributed to a misconception. In any case, your note makes a very valid point that needs to be heard.
Julia - My apologies if I have hurt your feelings. My thoughts go out to you. Your story, and those of others who have not been lucky enough to recover entirely, deserve to be heard.

Training for racing requires pushing the limits but allowing for recovery. You should not be training to keep up with clubmates but at the right pace for you. (I'm a Daniels fan.) Build mileage gradually. Build a base. (Think NYC during easy runs in February.) Marathon-training is longer but much less intense than focusing on a 10K.

You know all of this. Yet there's always the if-I-just-go-a-little-faster/longer/harder-it'll save-15-seconds-on-raceday demon whispering in the ear and Prefontaine's infamous "it's all about guts" (no, Steve, it's genes too) mantra hanging in the air.

The question I ask about how realistic a time-goal is is what's your HM PR? Double and add 10. That doesn't mean you'll do it. But it means, I think, that you can do it if you train smartly. Your objective should be to run your best. 3:00 is an arbitrary number, as is 26.21875.

Also, take a look at Malcolm Gladwell's New Yorker piece on Alberto Salazar from a few months back. They discuss the reality that different runners react differently to pain. Not stress-fracture pain but quads-exploding pain.

Finally, I have few credentials in this marathoning business, having completed only 2, 23 years apart. They were under 3. I gave up on doing another because I don't like the long, boring work it entails. That's also a personality thing. Get better, don't settle for mediocrity, and go for it In his book, Charlie Spedding says the objective of a workout is that it be "perfect". Not "hard". "Perfect".

I never moved from the 1200 sq. ft. 1950's bungalow that I bought in my 20s; partly because it was a mere 7 miles from work. Many of my contemporaries wanted those new houses on the edge of town because they were bigger (older homes run 1200 sq. ft., newer, 1600-2000) and, of course, newer. I heard the phrase "I don't want somebody else's problems" from three different couples - always from the wife side, actually.

For people willing to live the lifestyle of the boomer's parents - that 1200 sq. ft., meaning if you have 3 kids, two have to share a room; some home reno required, etc - close-in housing is not that hard to find in our city. People seem to put a premium on shiny-new over pre-owned with houses as well as cars.

We managed to pay off the mortgage by the time I was in my early 40's, and we could have considered a move to a bigger place, but that was when middle-age spread hit. I started walking 1.5 miles to the train, and that helped. A year later I found that in summer I could cycle the 7 miles a smidge faster, and that was even better for my waistline.

So this article reads like truth to me: I hear one younger person after another say they can't afford to live in the "inner" city (read: suburbs when they were built in the 1950s, now a third the commute distance of current suburbs) - and when I show them similar prices in my neighbourhood, they look at the smaller, 60-year-old building that looks it and laugh, "I'm not living in that".

I don't see how this is exclusive to the 1%. I know it's hard to fathom, but not everyone sees a large house with a yard as a must-have. My husband and I are not the only middle class family staying in the city and planning to use the public school system (we live in Boston, contrary to my out of date profile). We decided that public transportation and a walkable, vibrant  community were more important than a large house and a yard--in fact, I really could care less about those two things so I don't consider it a sacrifice (especially since we live near several parks). So while this article may not apply to you because you can't image living in an apartment or condo, and you think only billionaires can live in the city, please realize that there is a growing portion of the middle class that is putting community above America's ridiculously oversized houses and property--and who are choosing to support urban public school systems.
And if we had a good voucher and tax credit program, families could live in the city and have a diversity of educational options. It is a matter of social justice.

No one loves a long commute. But by moving to distant suburbs, middle class people are usually trying to achieve the same things that wealthy and upper middle class people also want -- good schools, fresh air, a yard big enough to play in, a house they can afford, perhaps a parent who can stay home.

One can achieve these things in an urban area -- but only at tremendous cost. At a certain point, both people working more than full-time so that you can afford a small apartment and a private school since starts to feel crazy. Sure you can walk to a farmers market on the weekends, but the rest of the time, you think "why do this when there are other options?" Of course, the public schools should be better, urban areas should be less expensive and suburbs should be reconfigured to reduce car travel. In the meantime, we all make choices about which trade offs are best for us personally.

You know, there are lots of intellectuals in America who read the NYTimes but who do not come from the 1%. These kinds of articles, which are about influencing the 1% to change their lifestyle from say, multi million dollar mansion in CT to multi million dollar apartment in NYC are just boring and annoying. Can you start a separate section for this?

You cannot work and homeschool at the same time - not if you're doing a decent job at either. I work from home 3 days per week in a job that demands my attention. I can usually do a load of laundry or two (put clothes in washer, work 65 minutes; put clothes in dryer, work 37 minutes; repeat), but folding usually happens after the kids go to bed. How does one work and, at the same time, educate one or more children? How does one send an email to a boss while explaining long division? Computers are not a substitute for interactive teachers, particularly not for younger children. Absurd.
My three work from home days are my gym days - I have time to go because I don't have the commute that day. it's built into my schedule.

There is a picture of a person squinting due to obvious sun in their eye. Many of the photo's use models with far too much make up and poor lighting who were perhaps told to make a face showing an emotion. There are too many confounding variables to mention. But for a study like this to have any true validity - there would have needed to be done a pre-study to make sure the photo's actually show the emotion you label as correct. Considering the quite obvious person squinting from the sun in their eye's, labeled despondent, I'm imagining this wasn't done. First, you would need photo's of people actually experiencing the emotion (think Duchenne smile vs. fake smile studies). With that all in place, this test would be something more than what I would expect to find in a tabloid.

To go further, using just the area around the eyes is not the true key to detecting emotion - accuracy would depend on mouth, cheeks, and eyes. Though this is good for entertainment.

Tho' not explicitly stated the parallels between Germany's financial policies and our own are only too obvious, with this mighty difference.

Germany manipulates its economy to benefit its country as a whole, even when Germany's gain is painful loss to other countries in its union. Regardless of the reason (many convincing ones were mentioned in earlier comments), for Germans it's Germany first, and one predictable consequence of that set of policies is that wealth concentrated in one country and not shared with others leads elsewhere to the kind of depressed economies and growing inequality we in the United States have become only too familiar with internally.

Here, our depressed economy and growing inequality also derive from economic policies, which are not designed to benefit the country as a whole, that is, our fast-fracturing union, but instead corporations and individuals, who like Germany, have amassed great wealth--and do not choose to, even resist sharing it with others.

Instead, our wealthy, like Germany and its moralists, preach austerity--for the poor.

This whole union thing sounds good, but in both Europe and here, kinda makes you wonder what union means, doesn't it?

Doesn't appear to mean much.

Thanks, Mr. Roddy, for making a point I hadn't thought of. Now I will.

But I'm not sure I get the connection between German economic policies and their appreciation of the steady-state economy you suggest....but as I said, I'll keep thinking.

Right now, I'm just not sure German motives are as far-seeing and insightful as your instinct tells you they might be.

Hello Mike,
I tend to agree with you but would suggest that spending could be on new tech that is much lower in carbon intensity to move everyone forward as a way to not punish people for needing to make a living.

There are more than enough reasons to criticize USA policy in any area of economic or social activity, but the issue addressed by Mr. Krugman here, has nothing to do with the points that you bring up.

"Steady-state economy", whatever that is supposed to mean, is senseless for any number of reasons, not least, as I normally note, because at base economic systems permit the swapping of everyone's labor, ultimately more or less for everyone's benefit.

Artificially preventing that swapping of labor makes no sense.

Maybe the time is right to abandon economic shibboleths, such as "healthy" 3% growth, along with plenty of consumer demand. Paul, have you done the math on what happens to the earth's natural resources if global growth continues at 3%? Global warming will probably get us first (http://www.lasthours.org), but continued global demand for more salad shooters and great rooms will crash earth's living systems.

We need to switch to a steady state economy, and allow the banks to feel the pain, depressing their assets and destroying the incomes of all of the predatory investment bankers themselves. We can also wake up to the frivolity of buying endless consumer goods delivered by polluting supertankers.

My instinct is that the Germans have figured that out on some level, which also explains why they are at the opposite pole of the US in taking serious action to slow global warming. It's time to listen to them, instead of lecturing them. Otherwise, our corrupt and bloated petro state will take the whole world down with us.

It seems Germany isn't making its current account surplus based on exports to europe but to the developing world. People here like and need German quality cars, machines and chemicals.

American quality would be good enough in most cases, but US companies tend to be less geared toward exports, which is not surprising given the insular mentality of most US citizens. Unless there are bombs to be dropped somewhere, Americans don't bother even learning geography, much less a foreign language.

This was a very enlightening article. It seems to me that the root of the problems Europe is having is that by having a common currency, there are no market forces to counter abuses and excesses of individual states. If Greece had its own currency, then its profligate spending would have caused their currency to be grossly devalued triggering hyperinflation. If Germany had its own currency, then its massive trade surplus would have greatly increased the value of its currency, causing its goods to rise in price and reduce its surplus. Also, by having one common currency, Germany can force its austerity policy onto other nations.

I'm certainly no expert in global economics, but if capital is flowing into Germany, then it can't flow into the depressed economies where it can be used to stimulate demand and investment.

It appears believing that spending less and hoarding capital will stimulate growth, has gripped Europe just as it has here in the US. Battling the evil debt monster has kept the US in a terribly weakened state and it's crushed Europe. How much more evidence is required to convince leaders that austerity is not stimulative? If their trade balance continues to grow, there wont be anyone in Europe with enough money to buy the German exports. Then Europe will be continuously depressed, reinforcing our continuous weakness. Economies operate upon demand. Supply is created in response to demand. Austerity and "me first" economics is killing recovery.
